p: The study area straddles the traditional territory of several Indigenous communities for which trapping is an important cultural and subsistence activity [ 53, 54]. Some trappers in the region are concerned about a decline in marten catches, which have been observed with concomitant increases in fisher catches (Fig. 2). Other trappers are concerned about a decrease in fishers in some parts of the region. Our preliminary conversations with trappers (both Indigenous and non-Indigenous) have suggested intra-regional variability in the evolution of fisher and marten abundances. Trapline area averages 100 km 2 in Abitibi-Témiscamingue (minimum area = 21 km 2 and maximum area = 643 km 2 for 498 traplines).
